column2: Shallow cavity of the coxa for articulation of the head of the femur.
Lateral projection of the spine of scapula.
Standing upright, facing forward with arms at the side and palms facing forward.
Toward the front.
Part of the skeleton that consists of the bones of the pectoral and pelvic girdls, arms, and legs.
Joint between the atlas (C1 vertebrae) and the axis (C2 vertebrae), used for turning the head side to side.
Joint between the atlas (C1 vertebrae) and occipital bone, used for nodding the head.
Roughened joint surface for articulation of the sacrum.
Part of the skeleton that consists of the bones of the head and trunk.
Superior bar of the pubis.
Central portion of the sternum where ribs articulate.
Toward the cheek.
Roughened attachment site at the posterior calcaneus.
Large bone that forms the heel.
Porous bone found at the ends of long bones and within flat and irregular bones.
Conical teeth with a single pointed cusp used to puncture a food item.
The 8 bones of the wrist
Anterior body of vertebra; the main weight-bearing element of the vertebra.
Neck region that contains 7 vertebrae.
The collarbone, which connects the sternum to the scapula to form the pectoral girdle.
Small triangular bone that projects from the inferior part of sacrum.
Hook-shaped projection from the anterior surface of the scapula.
An imaginary line that divides the body into anterior and posterior halves.
Joint that connects the frontal bone to the paired parietal bones.
Triangular eminence from the superior part of the mandibular ramus.
Triangular projection from the anterior surface of proximal ulna.
Dense, outer surface of bone.
Fibrous joints that connect bones of the skull and face.
Bones of the head that support the brain and face.
Small openings in the superior plate of the ethmoid that transmit olfactory nerves.
Lateral projection for attachment of deltoid muscle.
Partial joint surfaces on the lateral surface of the centrum of thoracic vertebrae.
Projection from superior surface of centrum of C2.
Shaft or central part of a long bone.
Further away from the center of the body or point of attachment.
Process of bone formation that occurs from a cartilage model.
End of long bones.
Unpaired bone of the skull that separates the nasal cavity from the brain.
Projection from the occipital superior to nuchal lines.
Long bone of the thigh.
Lateral bone of the leg.
Bones that are flat with thin layers of cortical bone surrounding cancellous bone.
Large opening in the occipital where the spinal cord passes.
An unpaired bone that forms the anterior and superior part of the cranium.
Part of the forehead between the eyebrows.
Shallow depression for the articulation of the head of the humerus.
Roughened attachment site for the gluteus maximus muscle.
Posterior border of the mandible at the junction of the ramus and body.
Large indentation of the ilium.
Large projection from the lateral surface of the proximal femur.
Large projection on the superior and lateral surface of the humerus.
Posterior part of the rib that articulates with the centrum.
Long bone of the arm.
U-shaped bone in the neck that does not articulate with another bone.
Large flat bone of the superior part of the coxa.
Toward the cutting edge.
Flat and shovel shaped teeth that are used to bite into a food item.
Away from the head or downward.
Inferior projections from the vertebral arch that connect to superior articular processes of the inferior vertebra.
Scroll-like paired bones that attach to the lateral part of the nasal cavity.
Fibrocartilaginous joints that connect adjacent centra of vertebrae.
Process of bone formation that occurs in mesenchyme and gives rise to flat bones of the skull.
Bones that have a complex appearance.
Thin, square projection from the ischium.
Large, round protrusion of the posterior and inferior ischium.
Thin bar of bone that unites the pubis and ischium.
The posterior and inferior portion of the os coxae.
Anterior curvature of the spine.
Paired bones that form the anterior and medial part of the orbit.
Joint that connects the parietal and occipital bones.
Flattened portion of the vertebral arch.
Further away from the midline.
Prominence of the distal fibula that forms the outer part of the ankle.
Projection from the medial surface of the proximal femur.
Projection on the anterior and superior surface of the humerus.
Elongated projection of the posterior surface of the femur.
Toward the tongue.
Bones that are longer than they are wide.
Posterior curvature of the spine.
Lower back region that consists of 5 vertebrae.
Lower jaw bone.
Rounded projection of the mandibular ramus.
Depression at the base of the temporal bone where the mandibular condyle articulates to form the temporomandibular (or jaw) joint.
Upper part of the sternum.
Bony projection from the back of the temporal bone.
Upper jaw bone.
Toward the midline.
Prominence of the distal tibia that forms the inner part of the ankle.
Central cavity in the diaphysis of long bones that contains bone marrow.
Triangular projection at the front of the mandible.
Toward the middle.
The 5 bones of the palm of the hand.
Junction between diaphysis and epiphysis where bone growth occurs.
The 5 bones at the distal part of the foot.
Joint that connects paired frontal bones and usually fuses early in childhood.
Plane that divides the body vertically into equal left and right halves. It is also called the medial plane, because it occurs on the midline of the body.
Teeth with flatter cusps that are used to grind food prior to swallowing.
Anterior opening of the nasal cavity.
Paired bones that form the bridge of the nose and the roof of the nasal cavity.
Bony projection from the inferior part of the nasal aperture.
Bones of the cranium that protects the brain.
Ridges on occipital from attachment of neck and back muscles.
Irregularly shaped opening within the pubis and ischium.
Unpaired bone at the posterior and base of the skull.
Toward the chewing surface.
Posterior projection of the proximal ulna.
Bony cavity that houses the eye and associated structures.
Hip bone, forms from the fusion of the ilium, ischium, and pubis.
Cell that secretes the matrix for bone formation.
A multinucleated bone cell that resorbs bone tissue during growth and repair.
Mature bone cell that lies within the bone matrix.
Stem cells that differentiate into osteoblasts.
The study of bones.
Paired bones that form the posterior part of the hard palate.
A vertical imaginary line adjacent to the sagittal plane that divides the body into unequal halves.
Paired bones forming the lateral walls of the cranium.
Knee cap; a bone that forms in the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle.
Projection that connects the lamina to the centrum.
The 14 bones of the digits.
Toward the back.
Teeth with two rounded cusps that are used to grind and mash a food item.
Closer to the center of the body or point of attachment.
Flat projections of the sphenoid that serve as attachment sites for chewing muscles and muscles of the throat.
Joint surface that unites the two pubic bones anteriorly.
Anterior and inferior portion of the coxa.
Rough projection for attachment of biceps brachii muscle.
Lateral bone of the forearm.
Bar-like portion of the posterior mandible.
Posterior part of the rib that articulates with the transverse process.
Triangular bone at the base of the spine that consists of 5 fused vertebrae.
An imaginary line that divides the body into left and right halves.
Joint that connects the parietal bones.
Flat, triangular bone that connects the upper limb to the pectoral girdle.
Bones that form within a tendon.
Bones that are as wide as they are long.
Unpaired bone that forms the anterior part of the base of the skull.
Elongated ridge on posterior surface.
Posterior projection of vertebral arch at the junction of the lamina.
Joint that connects the parietal and temporal bones.
Anterior part of rib that connects to the sternal body through costal cartilage.
Breastbone; flat bone of the anterior chest wall.
Thin projection from the base of the temporal bone.
Projection from the distal radius.
Projection from the distal ulna.
Depression below the pubic symphysis to the ischiopubic rami.
Toward the head.
Superior projections from the vertebral arch that connect to inferior articular processes of the superior vertebra.
External ridge at the superior part of the orbit.
Ankle bone that articulates with the tibia.
The 7 bones at the proximal end of foot; talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuneiforms (medial, intermediate, lateral), and cuboid.
Paired bones at the lateral and base of the skull that contain the middle and inner ear.
Ridges on the parietal bone from attachments of temporalis muscle and fascia.
Long process that forms the anterior half of the zygomatic arch.
Trunk region that consists of 12 vertebrae that attach to ribs.
Medial bone of the leg.
Roughened attachment site on the anterior surface of the proximal tibia.
An imaginary line that divides the body into superior and inferior halves.
Lateral projection at the junction of the pedicle and lamina.
Medial bone of the forearm.
Circular ring of bone at the posterior vertebra.
Cavity that contains the spinal cord.
Opening formed by the vertebral arch.
Bones of the cranium that make up the face skeleton.
Unpaired bone that forms the inferior part of the bony nasal septum.
Lower part of the sternum.
Synovial joints between the superior and inferior articular processes.
Bridge of bone at the cheek.
Paired bones that form the anterior and lateral parts of the mid-face.
Long process that forms the posterior half of the zygomatic arch.
Portion of the bone that articulates with the zygomatic bone to form the anterior portion of the zygomatic arch.
